---
title: "Neighborhood Effects"
---

## Overview

Do neighborhoods matter for individual outcomes? This lecture examines the evidence on neighborhood effects - how the characteristics of the places where people live influence their economic mobility, health, education, and other life outcomes.

## Key Topics

- What are neighborhood effects?
  - Peer effects and social interactions
  - Role models and aspirations
  - Local institutions (schools, police, services)
  - Networks and job referrals
  - Environmental quality
  - Safety and crime

- Identifying causal effects
  - Selection problem: why do people live where they do?
  - Natural experiments
  - Moving to Opportunity (MTO) experiment
  - Quasi-experimental methods

- Evidence on neighborhood effects
  - Educational outcomes
  - Employment and earnings
  - Health outcomes
  - Criminal behavior
  - Intergenerational mobility

- The Opportunity Atlas
  - Where in the U.S. do children have the best chances?
  - Geographic variation in upward mobility
  - The role of place in economic opportunity

## Policy Implications

- Should we help people or help places?
- Mobility programs vs. place-based policies
- Housing vouchers and residential mobility
- Community development initiatives
